data.title: Guit[ar]ithmetics Hero
data.statement:
You are amongst the best guitar players of the world. What people usually call a Guitar Hero. But one day, you are offered a challenge: to show that you truly are the best, you must mix guitar and maths.

On a standard guitar, there are 6 strings, floating over a fretboard of 21 frets. Each string can be played either open (no finger) or with a finger placed on a fret. Each such position corresponds to a unique number.

The numbering of the fretboard is defined as follows:
- Each string has {{22}} possible notes (open string + 21 frets).
- The open string of the 1st string is numbered {{1}}.
- Each fret increases the number by {{1}}.
- Numbering continues string by string.
- The 21st fret (22nd position) of the 6th string is numbered {{132}}.

Several notes played together make a chord.

A chord is written as 6 values separated by hyphens, one per string:
- A number between {{1}} and {{21}} means the string is played on that fret.
- {{0}} means the string is played open.
- {{X}} means the string is not played and should be ignored.

{{Note}}: The strings are numbered from 1 to 6 in the order in which they appear in the input.

Here is an example for the chord C: X-3-2-0-1-0
This means: 
- the first string is not played, indicated by the {{X}}: {{no value}}
- the second string has a finger on fret {{3}}: the value is {{26}}
- the third string has a finger on fret {{2}}: the value is {{47}}
- the fourth string is an open string: the value is {{67}}
- the fifth string is played with a finger on fret {{1}}: the value is {{90}}
- the sixth string is an open string: the value is {{111}}
- The {{output}} will then be the sum of all these values: {{341}}

Your task is to translate the played notes of the given chords and output the sum.
data.constraints:
1 ≤ [[chordsCount]] ≤ 22
Each [[chord]] contains exactly 6 notes
Fret values are between {{0}} and {{21}}.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You are amongst the best guitar players of the world. What people usually call a Guitar Hero. But one day, you are offered a challenge: to show that you truly are the best, you must mix guitar and maths.

On a standard guitar, there are 6 strings, floating over a fretboard of 21 frets. Each string can be played either open (no finger) or with a finger placed on a fret. Each such position corresponds to a unique number.

The numbering of the fretboard is defined as follows:
- Each string has 22 possible notes (open string + 21 frets).
- The open string of the 1st string is numbered 1.
- Each fret increases the number by 1.
- Numbering continues string by string.
- The 21st fret (22nd position) of the 6th string is numbered 132.

Several notes played together make a chord.

A chord is written as 6 values separated by hyphens, one per string:
- A number between 1 and 21 means the string is played on that fret.
- 0 means the string is played open.
- X means the string is not played and should be ignored.

Note: The strings are numbered from 1 to 6 in the order in which they appear in the input.

Here is an example for the chord C: X-3-2-0-1-0
This means:
- the first string is not played, indicated by the X: no value
- the second string has a finger on fret 3: the value is 26
- the third string has a finger on fret 2: the value is 47
- the fourth string is an open string: the value is 67
- the fifth string is played with a finger on fret 1: the value is 90
- the sixth string is an open string: the value is 111
- The output will then be the sum of all these values: 341

Your task is to translate the played notes of the given chords and output the sum.
Input
Line 1: An integer chordsCount to indicate the number of incoming chords.
Next chordsCount lines: A string chord containing the notes of the current chord, each note being separated by a hyphen.
Output
An integer representing the sum of each played note within each chord.
Constraints
1 ≤ chordsCount ≤ 22
Each chord contains exactly 6 notes
Fret values are between 0 and 21.
Example
Input
1
0-X-X-X-X-X
Output
1
